instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPSUB_G3H: What is PPSUB_G3H? This is a typo of PPBUS_G3H When you see PPSUB_G3H, assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.820-1494: What is 820-1494? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H_REG: What is PP3V42_G3H_REG? PP3V42_G3H_REG is another way to say PP3V42_G3H. PP3V42_G3H_REG and PP3V42_G3H are a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P5VS3_PGOOD: What is P5VS3_PGOOD? P5VS3_PGOOD indicates that the PP5V_S3 power rail is functioning properly..
definitions.P5VS5_EN: What is P5VS5_EN? P5VS5_EN is a signal that turns on the PP5V_S5 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S5_PGOOD: What is P3V3S5_PGOOD? P3V3S5_PGOOD is a signal that denotes that the PP3V3_S5 power rail is working..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Good evening,

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A logic board with amber and green light on the charger. The board is currently out of the MacBook,and not connected to anything besides the charger.

I measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on the fuse F7140.  
Pin1: 12.68V
Pin2: 0V

I unplugged the board, tested the fuse with diode mode; probes on pin 2 and ground => Beep. I also measured 0.1 Ohms.
Problem seems similar to what was described there : [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a-<SIGNAL>PPSUB_G3H</SIGNAL>-shorted-ground.7292/[/URL]

dukefawks and aprendiz asked the resistance to ground from  F7140 to L7320. Original author didnt reply. 
On my board, I have 0.5ohms on pin 2 of L7320, but it decreases to 0.0 in 5-6 sec.
I have 0 ohm on pin 1 of L7320

There is no sign of corrosion, no sign of liquid, board has not been cleaned; there is still dust a bit everywhere, but almost nothing.

Nothing get hot.

How do I narrow down the cause of the problem ? And if there was no liquid, then what might have caused a short?

P.S: Was I supposed to post under the old thread, 6y old, or create a new one ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
"resistance to ground from  F7140 to L7320"
Incorrect expression; try to understand what you read on the forum.

In this case, you must check resistance between F7140 and L7320; not to ground.
Checking to ground will give similar short on both, which points to shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>/20.
That's the reason of this check, mentioned in that post.

I you have short to ground at L7310/20, CPU is dead most likely.
Lift L7310/20 one side and find where is the short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7311</TRANSISTOR>/21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Hi 2informaticos, thanks for your help;
I guarantee you that I try to understand what I read...

Here are the measurements:
Resistance between F7140, pin1, and pin1&2 of L7320 is 399 Ohms.
Resistance between F7140, pin1, and pin1&2 of L7310 is 402 Ohms.
And Resistance between F7140, pin 1, and ground : 399 Ohms, as above

I'm not even sure that I have to measure from pin1 of F7140.
If I measure from pin2 of F7140, to pin1&2 of L7310/20, I get 0.1 Ohm.
Current goes from the charger to this pin 1

Problem is, I do not understand the rationale.
How do you know that there is a path, before any measurement, between pin1 of F7140 and L7310/20? It's not obvious to me.
What if the measure was infinite resistance? How would I make the difference between "it's normal, there is actually no path" and "the path is 'broken' for some reason" ?
On the schematics, page 56, current flows through L7310/7320 from pin 1 to pin 2; it gives <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_REG</SIGNAL> (OUT). Ok fine.
Before that, current flows through <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>/21 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>/11. Before, it seems to come from <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>, which seems to come from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, which....
I can't find the path back to F7140, pin1.


I did what you asked, but again, I dont understand all the logic behind everything, unfortunately. If you could explain just a little bit more your reasoning regarding the "why", it would be very much appreciated ☺.

I lifted L7310 and L7320.
[ATTACH type="full" alt="<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1494</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A L7310 L7320 - Copie.jpg"]60859[/ATTACH].
L7310 lifted looks fine, I have 9120 Ohm between pin 1 and ground.
On pin 1/2/3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>, and on pin 5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7311</TRANSISTOR>, I also have this value, as expected.

L7320 does not look fine, I have 0 Ohm between pin 1 and ground.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>/21 dont look fine; I've 0Ohm all over the place, pin 1 to 5 on each.


The owner of this MacBook said that the last time he turned on the MacBook, everything was fine until the desktop appeared; then the mac suddenly crashed. He tried to turn it on again, but this time the crash occured during the boot, just after the apple logo. Eventually, he tried to turn it on a third time, but there was no third time: No boot at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
"If I measure from pin2 of F7140, to pin1&2 of L7310/20, I get 0.1 Ohm."
What do you expect measuring from pin 1, if F7140 is burnt (open)?
Please, put some logic on your job.

The forum purpose is to help in the repair process.
Personal training is different thing.
You can still learn a lot reading as many threads as possible.

Can't you see any path F7140 -> <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> -> L7320 -> CPU core voltage???

You are lucky if only <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>/21 are the burnt components; maybe <CHIP>U7320</CHIP> too (less probably).
However, was expecting resistance to ground on the other side of L7320.
To know if CPU may still be alive.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
[LIST]
[*]"What do you expect measuring from pin 1, if F7140 is burnt (open)? "

If I measure the resistance from pin1 of F7140 [I]to ground[/I], which is 8.3 kOhms (and identical to the measure from pin 1 of L7130 to ground, pin 2 of L7310 to ground, etc), then I get the resistance of the circuitry between the measurement point and the ground.
And I get this 8300 Ohms because the fuse is burnt. If it was not burnt, I would measure another resistance, very likely higher.

If I measure the resistance from pin1 of F7140 [I]to pin1 L7310/20[/I], I m not sure about what to expect, I'm confused, and that's why I'm here.
A first guess would be : Since the path through the fuse is broken (open circuit), I actually measured the resistance of "everything" between pin 1 of F7140 and pin 1 of L7310/7320, assuming there is a path. Measurements show that there is one, otherwise resistance would be infinite. And there is no short on this part otherwise I would read 0.0 Ohm. Is it wrong ?

I'm way more interested in understanding all the rationale behind what I'm told to do, rather than in fixing the board. Understanding is more valuable than a board....

With the black probe on pin 1 of F7140 and red probe on pin 1 below lifted L7310, I get 10.85kOhms
With the red probe on pin 1 of F7140 and black probe on pin 1 below lifted L7310, I get 9.8kOhms
With the black probe on pin 1 of F7140 and red probe on pin 1 below lifted L7320, I get 0.850kOhms
With the redprobe on pin 1 of F7140 and black probe on pin 1 below lifted L7320, I get 7.85kOhms

With the black probe on pin 1 of F7140 and red probe on ground, I get 410 Ohms
With the red probe on pin 1 of F7140 and black probe on ground, I get 8.25 kOhms




[*]"The forum purpose is to help in the repair process. Personal training is different thing."

If there is a way to aquire above knowledge quickly, I'm totally ready to pay for this, or even for a detailed answer.
I've spent the day on the schematics and Google browsing/reading but I essentially found infos that I already knew; not what I was looking for.
I would be interested in "personal training" on a pay-per-question/per-hour basis, if providing the rationale that I currently miss is what you call "personal training". I do not think I would need to ask twice the same question. Let me know in PM if you do this😊, at which cost for 15minutes ?



[*]"You can still learn a lot reading as many threads as possible. "

True, but answers are sometimes just a little bit too much "repair oriented", straight to the point, and the rationale is not necessarily explained. Some threads don't have any conclusion/feedback, OP didnt answer to the questions asked, etc.
Don't get me wrong please🙏, the above are not negative critics, just observations. Besides, this forum is great as it is, and given its purpose it makes sense. I did read the terms of use, etc, I am not complaining of anything. I'm thankful/grateful for the answers and your time.
Nevertheless, I would like to avoid behaving like a donkey who would just "do this" then "that" because he reads this and that. Again, I'm not criticizing anything/anybody.




[*]"Can't you see any path F7140 -> <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> -> L7320 -> CPU core voltage???"

I do see a path from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, which receives the 5V voltage regulator:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR_VIN</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCST</SIGNAL>
and creates pulse with modulation to CPU, <SIGNAL>CPU_PWM2</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CPU_PWM1</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CPUVR_FCCM</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL>,
to <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7320</CHIP> via <SIGNAL>CPU_FCCM</SIGNAL> and _PWM1/2.
I do see the path to <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>, L7320, and to <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_REG</SIGNAL>

What I do not see is the path between F7140 and the rest; F7140's output is <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
It seems that from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> we get <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_REG</SIGNAL>, but I dont see the path between this and the 5V. I will keep reading the schematics tomorrow and update this post, should I find it before you read me


[*]"I was expecting resistance to ground on the other side of L7320."
[COLOR=rgb(41, 105, 176)]Resistance from Ground (black) to pin 2 of L7320 is 14.3 Ohms
Resistance from Ground (black) to pin 2 of L7310 is 14.4 Ohms[/COLOR]

Is there still a chance for the CPU to be alive ? I checked on a an untouched-still-in-the-macbook working board, I had 150 Ohms, but with L7320/7310 unlifted. Would need to unlift it to check wether it is relevant.
[/LIST]

Thanks for your time so far☺

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
"What do you expect measuring from pin 1, if F7140 is burnt (open)? "
I mean from pin 1 to L7310/20, which is where you've checked.
Open fuse, how can indicate something in such case???
Was especially mentioned checking from fuse to some components, not to ground.
Please, make use of logic!

"between pin 1 of F7140 and pin 1 of L7310/7320, assuming there is a path."
What path, if fuse is open???
You MUST check from pin 2 (output) to the rest of board!
I can't believe that you've still wasted time checking from pin 1 of (burnt) F7140.

14 ohm is a good reading for VCORE, you may be lucky.
Just change the mentioned components.
Don't forget to replace F7140, at the end.

Dificult to understand how do you see a path from 5V to VCORE, but not from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
What do you think these very powerful MOSFETs (Q73xx) do there?
If you expect VCORE generation from 5V, what's the reason to have them?

Feel free to send a PM, if you require another information, regardless online assistance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Thanks; I will come back on this part of the issue asap, give it a xth thought, and answer the questions.

However, I must apologize because I was working on 2 similar boards and while I checked the presence of <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> on the second one, I forgot to do it on this one...

I suddenly realized that I have [B]no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>[/B] on this one neither => I did new measurements on [B]<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> [/B]to check whether I had _S5.

On the schematics page 58, there is a "[B]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>[/B]" which is not named like this on the boardview, and must be at 5V, as VOUT. Problem is, I measured on pin 14, I have 0.31V. So, for some reason, this <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is NOT ouputing 5V.

Measurements on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>:

pin 14, pin 29, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>: [COLOR=rgb(226, 80, 65)]0.31V => Problem[/COLOR]

pin 21, <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> : 3.33V
pin 20, <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL>: 3.34V
-> the chip receives <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> and send <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> [COLOR=rgb(26, 188, 156)]=>OK[/COLOR]

pin 12, <SIGNAL>P5VS5_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.38V same as <SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> same as <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> (page 64 "S5 Enable") [COLOR=rgb(26, 188, 156)]=>OK[/COLOR]

pin 4: <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL> : [COLOR=rgb(251, 160, 38)]0V[/COLOR]; but if _S5 not present on pin 14, not surprising.
pin 5: <SIGNAL>P5VS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>: [COLOR=rgb(251, 160, 38)]0V[/COLOR]; again, if _S5 not present on pin 14, not surprising.
I wont check the other P5VS3 pins, no reason to have anything different from 0V.

pin 15: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_COMP2</SIGNAL> : 0V
pin 16: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VFB2</SIGNAL> : 0.165V
pin 3: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_RF</SIGNAL> : 0V
pin 17: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_CSN2</SIGNAL>: 0.55V
pin 18: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_CSP2</SIGNAL>: 0.55V
pin 24: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVH</SIGNAL>: 0.54V
pin 25: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_LL</SIGNAL>: 0.54V
pin 26: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_VBST</SIGNAL>: 0.41V
pin 27: <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_DRVL</SIGNAL>: 0V

So, in short:
[COLOR=rgb(41, 105, 176)]<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is told that P5VS5 is enabled on pin12.  It is also told that <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> is enabled on pin 21. The chip returns <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5_PGOOD</SIGNAL> on pin 20. 
However, it doesnot ouput the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> correctly (0.31V on pin14 and 29). Since this _S5 is not what it should, the chip cannot receive the <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL> because the P5VS3 is actually not enabled correctly, and therefore the chip returns 0V on pin 5 for <SIGNAL>P5VS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>.[/COLOR]

I tried to find the datasheet of <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> to learn more about it, didnt find it.

Is it possible that the short around the <TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>/20 might have killed the <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> ?

In that case I better find and fix the short first, then very likely replace <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, then replace the fuse.


"Feel free to send a PM, if you require another information, regardless online assistance."
Thanks for this 🙏

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
What can you expect from a board without F7140 (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground)?
Did you think where 5V comes from???

As already said, try to put logic on your job...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Regarding the short:
I had a very small resistance on pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>; 0 on the other pins.
And I had 0 ohms on all the pins of <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR>. I therefore removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR> first.

Now on the pins below <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR> I have:
pin 1/2/3: 0 Ohm, ground, as expected.
pin 4: >800kOhms
"pin5": >200kOhms

And on pins of <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>, I read >20kOhms on all pins.
So, short is gone and <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR> was the culprit.

"What can you expect from a board without F7140 (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground)?"
Did you think where 5V comes from??? 

Yes I did, and I hadn't the answer. I had wrongly supposed that it could be created from all the P3V3S5 currently at 0V, but I suddenly realized that I had completely missed the VIN pin 23, "<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER3V3_ISNS</SIGNAL>" which comes straight from G3H...which is not there...

Jeez I feel shameful.<SIGNAL>O_O</SIGNAL>

So. Will solder a new <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR> on that board, replace the fuse and we should be good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
"Will solder a new <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR> on that board, replace the fuse and we should be good."
I hope you don't do (only) that.
Don't you want to eliminate the short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L7320???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Well, I had measured resistance from pin 1 of L7320 (lifted) to ground, I had 0 Ohm; now that the dead <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR> is out of the board I have > 20kOhm. So, no short anymore on this side.

On pin 2,with L7320 lifted, I had 14 Ohms.

I soldered back the L7320, I read 10 Ohms now, lower because of the heat I guess.

L7310 is still lifted ; pin1 to ground: 8400 Ohms, pin2 to ground 10 Ohms

I dont get what makes your think that there is another short somewhere betweenPPBUS_G3H and L7320.

I did some measurement from a working board, though, and i get 150 Ohms on pin1/2 of L7320 and L7310.
Therefore, you're very likely right, there might still be issue somewhere, but I don't understand how you can infer that from the above mesurements. 🤔 🤔 🤔

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message: Edit: you're right, there is 0.1 Ohm resistance between pin2 of F7140 and pin 2 of my not-lifted L7320, so, there is still a problem, as you said

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Didn't change <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> yet???
Was mentioned in the first post.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Not yet, wanted to check everything I need prior to order the necessary components. 

As I said, I'm just starting with the logic board repairs; I dont have donor boards to harvest for these 13" 2015. I'm checking the usual/common failures on these models and filling my cart. Will receive everything in 2 days. Any suggestion is welcomed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
So, I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>, and now there is infinite resistance between pin2 of F7140 and pin 2 of my not-lifted L7320. No path anymore so...expected.

However, I have 0 resistance between pin2 of F7140 and pin 5 "below" <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> (removed). Not normal.

Pin 5 is <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>. This is also VIN of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> on pin 17. <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> creates <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL> goes into <CHIP>U7310</CHIP>/20, then to <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>...

P68 shows that <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL> is created from <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> but I don't find where,
and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. So. I assume it is normal that I do not have an infinite resistance between above pin 5 and pin2 of F7140. I'm stuck with that loo.

I guess I have to break the circuit at some other part to find where is the short causing the resistance between pin2 of F7140 and pin5 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> (removed) to be 0. But I can't figure out where. Remove <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>?

Going to replace <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>/<TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR> now

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
"I have 0 resistance between pin2 of F7140 and pin 5 "below" <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR> (removed). Not normal."
Why not normal???

Please, pay atention when you interpret the schematic!
Both mentioned points are connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; at least in my opinion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
well, since I did not find any direct connection point between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>, I assumed that the resistance should be different from 0. 
But you're very likely right, you have more experience than I have, obviously.

I replaced F7140, <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR>, put back in place L7310; L7320 was already back in place.

Time to clean, put this board back in the case and test if problem is fixed...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Almost fixed.
Now the MacBook is able to boot; but it takes 24 seconds. It's quite slow.
Furthermore, it does not see the battery anymore.
And at the end of the boot, the screen first displays an image on 70% of its surface, then switch to black, and then display the image on 100%. That's weird.

[ATTACH width="288px"]60867[/ATTACH][ATTACH width="291px"]60868[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
"I did not find any direct connection point between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>"
Take a better look at pages 68 & 42...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - burnt Fuse F7140 - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground?
threads.message:
Regarding my last post; the battery was dead, i replaced it, the macbook was able to boot properly then. The death of <TRANSISTOR>Q7320</TRANSISTOR>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7321</TRANSISTOR> probably caused to battery, or the battery caused the problem. Anyway, this part is sorted.
Regarding the image size on screen after boot, it was caused by the settings; everything was scaled down to display more info on screen.
Everything fixed so, thanks for your help 2informaticos

Regarding  "direct connection point between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>": Indeed. p68 shows that from <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> we get <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> gives <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS_R</SIGNAL>, which on page 42 sends back <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> (<CHIP>U5400</CHIP>) if it has  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>
